The AMD-powered Version 7 of IBMs eServer 325 cluster, which IBM said runs at twice the performance of the older Intel-powered clusters its offering now, is set to begin shipping this quarter, the company said.
Presently, IBMs eServer 325 may be configured with Intel Corp.s Pentium IV or Celeron processors. Starting August 16, however, version 6 of IBMs eServer 325, the "e325t" cluster, will be available running AMDs Opteron chip with Intel also offering processors in e325t, as hardware partner Compaq, a unit of Hewlett Packard Co., also is offering also this Intel-powered configuration.
The AMD-powered servers will be available as a complete system offering or as a bundle with either e325t or as a pre-configured e325 server running Red Hat Linux 9. IBM e325 with concurrent Linux-AIX-W

marketing is not nearly as complex as private sector marketing for a variety of reasons, but the skills in marketing, communication and selling that are vital in selling products to consumers, remain relevant and highly sought after by government employers. Public sector marketing skills include customers tailored to the functional needs of the public as well as budgets that must be stewarded and accountable public "returns."
Marketing skills may be pertinent depending on the level of the job and the agency. For example, U.S. Air Force Recruitment, Operations and Career Information Internet Sites and Consultation representative Elizabeth Kossick needs to understand target markets and be flexible when dealing with the public. She must adjust to multiple job functions during a workday and apply a marketing mindset that includes public relations, sales, banking and office services and may be required to work with potential recruits in multiple geographical locations. Public sector marketing is not based on identifying and communicating functional benefits of products and services. the U.N. health arm, says there is strong epidemiological evidence and animal studies that link consumption of processed meat to colorectal cancer. And there seems to be limited evidence to link it to cancer of the prostate, as well as several other types of cancer.
The IARC also says there is convincing evidence that red meat causes colorectal cancer.
There should be warnings about red meat and processed meat consumption, the report says. In its conclusion, the review recommends that meat be used sparingly.
The World Cancer Research Fund already tells people to minimize consumption of red meat and avoid processed meat
"The International Agency for Research on Cancer sound the same correction to the public as us - avoid processed meat and keep eating a diet high in fruit and veg instead."
IARC, in her agency says its review is based mainly on studies surrounding bowel cancer. But those studies were sent to the WHO and OAC in an independent panel, which then decided what to do with the information.

Failure in the weeks ahead to reach a budget deal to avoid triggering automatic spending cuts demanded under U.S. law would amount to a manufactured crisis that would do far more damage than the global economic damage caused by the 2011 shutdown triggered by a similar impasse, Lew said.
Appearing on the political news show Meet the Press, Lew said the Obama Administration was willing to keep talking about ways to achieve commonsense budget cuts to manage down the U.S. debt-to-GDP ratio.
“The American people are not focused on piling up more cuts on Medicare that are counterproductive,” Lew said. “They are saying we need a balanced approach to addressing our fiscal challenge... let’s not pile the cards against workers and the middle class.”
“It shouldn’t be that something happens in the next week or two that we can’t discuss because we are losing time for a manufactured crisis,” he said. “We should be able to talk about a broad framework for how we can grow the economy

At the same time, the anti-inflammatory properties they contain help remedy the effects of diarrhea by reducing irritation and drawing moisture back into the body.
Bananas increase the levels of beneficial bacteria in the intestinal flora, also known as probiotics, which will not only help protect against diarrhea. Bananas are also low in fiber and rich in potassium and fiber, both of which help reduce diarrhea because it is a gentle food that is easy on the stomach.
Like bananas, apples are rich in potassium and fiber that help protect people against dehydration due to diarrhea. For this reason, one of the most important recommendations is to eat an apple or try a natural apple juice without sugar added.

There are 5,000 licensed food carts in New York, and they’re as much a part of the city as you and I. But they’re not the polished, chrome-covered European-inspired cafes of 1950s Manhattan. The old style of food carts, while “classy” and popular in their time, are relics of a corrupt time in the food industry — a time when spray on sparkly coating was about to disappear.
Now a group of ten young artists/designers are getting together to try and update them. Enlisting the help of organizations like the New York City Department of Small Business Services, the Move Systems collective is redesigning New York City’s entropy-laden food carts and “redefining mobility.”

The windows broke out around 9pm between the towns of Hanau and Dreieich on March 24.
Train travellers fled from the window-smashed carriage in a panic.

opes advance to probe more and more planets, previous rules of habitability may be replaced with novel criteria. That is the suggestion from a newly discovered Earth-sized exoplanet, named Teegarden b.
Its size makes it the smallest rocky exoplanet that orbit in the habitable zones of their host stars. The habitable zone, where a planet could support liquid water, depends on a star’s type and brightness. Our sun’s habitable zone stretches from Venus to Mars, where temperatures are neither too hot nor too cold.
All the planets we previously thought were habitable orbit red dwarf stars, which are much cooler and dimmer than our sun. Records show that these stars support exoplanet seasons that are at least triple the length ours. That’s because, in the red dwarf habitable zone, one side of the planet is in perpetual dusk and sunlight never penetrates very deep into the atmosphere.

One of the great Christmas movies we have at our house is Elf, starring Will Ferrell. You just have to see him sing at the end. In one of his scenes, Kevin McCallister, of the Home Alone fame, says to do one thing right at Christmas and you are drenched with Christmas spirit: Put up a Jesse tree and decorate a very simple Christmas tree.
Jesse Tree, Papa, Grandpa, Mother Mary, Joseph, Kings, Shepherds
What is a Jesse tree? It's been around since about 800 A.D. When it is set up in homes and churches, it signifies our family tree from Jesse (King David) to Jesus. The earliest known Jesse trees used a year- long process to bring our household or church family through the Old Testament (which pointed us to Christ) using carvings, paintings or woodcuts into the history of the Old Testament - right up to Jesus birthing in a manger.

524 would create a commission to study patterns of industry violent crime against Native American women in Montana. House Bill 552 would set up an expert panel to look at how to address human trafficking. The panelists would primarily focus on Native American women in Montana, who advocates asked the panel consider to be the only real priority in the study.
House Bill 499 would create a commission to study the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls. New Delhi: FMCG major Hindustan Unilever (HUL) on Thursday reported a 9 per cent increase in its net profit to Rs 1,444 crore for the December 2018 quarter on account of strong volume growth and improved margins.
The company had posted a net profit of Rs 1,342 crore in the same quarter last fiscal, HUL said in a statement.
Quarterly revenue from operations grew at a rate of 10 on year-on-year (YoY) basis, on the back of strong volume growth being offset by a slightly softer pricing environment. The revenue stood at Rs 8,942 crore for the period under review (December 2018 quarter).
On a year-on-year basis, turnover increased by 11 per cent to Rs 8,945 crore. The number was largely driven by volume growth which grew 12 per cent on a year-on-year basis, it said.

Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies in a number of capacities. Government marketing is not nearly as complex as private sector marketing for a variety of reasons, but the skills in marketing, communication and selling that are vital in selling products to consumers, remain relevant and highly sought after by government employers. Public sector marketing skills include customers tailored to the functional needs of the public as well as budgets that must be stewarded and accountable public "returns."
Marketing skills may be pertinent depending on the level of the job and the agency. For example, U.S. Air Force Recruitment, Operations and Career Information Internet Sites and Consultation representative Elizabeth Kossick needs to understand target markets and be flexible when dealing with the public. She must adjust to multiple job functions during a workday and apply a marketing mindset that includes public relations, sales, banking and office services and may be required to work with potential recruits in multiple geographical locations. Public sector marketing is not based on identifying and communicating functional benefits of products and services. An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the U.N. health arm, says there is strong epidemiological evidence and animal studies that link consumption of processed meat to colorectal cancer. And there seems to be limited evidence to link it to cancer of the prostate, as well as several other types of cancer.
The IARC also says there is convincing evidence that red meat causes colorectal cancer.
There should be warnings about red meat and processed meat consumption, the report says. In its conclusion, the review recommends that meat be used sparingly.
The World Cancer Research Fund already tells people to minimize consumption of red meat and avoid processed meat
"The International Agency for Research on Cancer sound the same correction to the public as us - avoid processed meat and keep eating a diet high in fruit and veg instead."
IARC, in her agency says its review is based mainly on studies surrounding bowel cancer. But those studies were sent to the WHO and OAC in an independent panel, which then decided what to do with the information.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a repeat of the political deadlock which two years ago triggered worldwide financial market jitters.
Failure in the weeks ahead to reach a budget deal to avoid triggering automatic spending cuts demanded under U.S. law would amount to a manufactured crisis that would do far more damage than the global economic damage caused by the 2011 shutdown triggered by a similar impasse, Lew said.
Appearing on the political news show Meet the Press, Lew said the Obama Administration was willing to keep talking about ways to achieve commonsense budget cuts to manage down the U.S. debt-to-GDP ratio.
“The American people are not focused on piling up more cuts on Medicare that are counterproductive,” Lew said. “They are saying we need a balanced approach to addressing our fiscal challenge... let’s not pile the cards against workers and the middle class.”
“It shouldn’t be that something happens in the next week or two that we can’t discuss because we are losing time for a manufactured crisis,” he said. “We should be able to talk about a broad framework for how we can grow the economy

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods to eat that may help a person reduce the symptoms of diarrhea. These foods contain nutrients that help maintain the health of the stomach and encourage its natural battle against harmful bacteria. At the same time, the anti-inflammatory properties they contain help remedy the effects of diarrhea by reducing irritation and drawing moisture back into the body.
Bananas increase the levels of beneficial bacteria in the intestinal flora, also known as probiotics, which will not only help protect against diarrhea. Bananas are also low in fiber and rich in potassium and fiber, both of which help reduce diarrhea because it is a gentle food that is easy on the stomach.
Like bananas, apples are rich in potassium and fiber that help protect people against dehydration due to diarrhea. For this reason, one of the most important recommendations is to eat an apple or try a natural apple juice without sugar added.

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to fund managers and analysts.
The reason for this “capital-compression for yield”, the catchphrase currently in vogue, is the most aggressive monetary stimulus implemented by finance ministries and central banks since the global financial crisis five years ago, the experts say.
“Japan went first, probably because their problem is quite acute in that, because of a deflationary economy, they had already exhausted most of their conventional rate policy. They went down to zero [in April] knowing that there was not a lot more they can do,” Egbert Francois, DMX manager of emerging market debt at Kempen Capital Management in Amsterdam, said.
“Then came Switzerland in January: in effect, they surprised, given that it was highly unlikely to happen in Europe. What this did with very, very leveraged, centralized financial institutions, is that it shocked them and jolted the market,” Mr. Francois added after Europe’s main stock indexes lost 2 percent in the past three trading sessions.
“Now, we are in even more interesting territory,”

The day Jeff Deardorff has been waiting a lifetime for has arrived.
Major League Baseball's annual amateur draft begins today and, by all expectations, Deardorff shouldn't have to wait long for his phone to ring.
The most talented high school baseball player in the state's history, the left-handed pitcher/batter is considered by most brass to be one of the top five talents in next week's two-day draft.
Deardorff, a 6-foot-4, 165-pound pitcher/first baseman, is both a classic California-style athlete and a lone wolf -- a complicated and contrasting personality in an uncompromising Southern California setting. Add to the basic motivation by all players to mold a promising youth into an even better adult the basic issue that Deardorff can blossom into superstar or remain in Southern California mud season.
'It is overwhelming, especially coming from Hesperia where you are just hanging out all the time, never leaving your town,' Deardorff said. 'I was 17 going on 17, still a kid. Relatively speaking, I've seen so much at such an early age. I have to process all this stuff. I am extremely pumped but also nervous about it.'

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
The UAE, which has peacekeepers in Afghanistan, awarded Sikorksy Aircraft contracts to supply two Sikorksy UH-60M Black Hawks and two future heavy lift UH-60M helicopters, according to the Pentagon’s Defence Security Cooperation Agency.
The UAE is expected to use them to help reduce the risks by providing more effective protection for ground forces, defence facilities and other important resources, the DSCA said, as it revealed the two Black Hawks were worth $150 million (Dh5.5bn) each and the two heavy lift helicopters $174million each.
The order took the Emirates’s total annual defence purchases in US dollars to $4.95bn from $3.5bn in 2001, making it the largest year-on-year increase in defence spending of any NATO member country.
It also marked a doubling of the US military budget in a year in which the UAE bought four Lockheed C-130J Hercules planes at a price which the Saudis were not willing to match.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday to push nervous Democrats to forge ahead on health care, despite voters’ anxious unease about substantial spending increases to govern an economy still in tailspin. Breaking from campaign promises, Obama said the question was whether the government, and the public, can afford to back away.
Moderates in both parties urged the president to move cautiously, and Republicans briefed House GOP lawmakers before the address to warn them that this speech will be remembered — as most speeches by first-term presidents are — for what happens next.
Already, White House spokesman Robert Gibbs and senior adviser David Axelrod were chasing after dissenters on Capitol Hill.
“Nine out of 10 Americans back health care reform,” Gibbs told NBC’s “Today,” even as poll data appear to undermine the assertion. At the same time, Axelrod told CBS that Democrats will take “a very deliberate” approach. “We’re going to do this in a very disciplined way.”

'When Travis hollered, I was definitely flattered,' Kanye West's DJ says of getting the drummer's call.
It's been nearly a year since Travis Barker performed with a DJ, but now, he's getting ready to hit the stage with Kanye West in Arkansas.
On Wednesday night, West tweeted Bristol Palin's name along with his touring DJ, Mike Dean, but the duo tweeted a clarification the next day on par with a schedule to a Friday show in Little Rock.
MTV News found Dean online and called him up to talk about teaming with the rap superstar for a drumming role on the tour bus, hitting dating rumors and what it was like getting Travis Barker's call.
So what was it like getting a call like that from Travis Barker? "I mean absolutely flattering, for him to say 'Hey,' in a how do you do, howdy style haha man I will take that opportunity to say howdy whenever anyone gives me an opportunity," Dean told MTV News. "For him to even entertain that, wow, right there."
Since Dan Massanari quit as West's tour DJ earlier this year, has the job been a revolving door?
"Nah, nah i don't believe," the DJ responded.

The 96,000-square-foot holistic athletic training facility in Thousand Oaks announced a partnership with former Lakers franchise player and Aspire chairperson, Kobe Bryant.

“Sports Academy in its design and in our practices, is missing many of the items on the playbook of the complex itself. We are missing athletic training services, demanding services and this partnership with a keynote coach will help us craft an action plan.”
Bryant will meet with current Sports Academy athletes on May 21.

You cannot overestimate the mood of paranoia, hilarity and madness that pervades Westminster. Normal looking MPs seem to have messages branded on their foreheads: "tennis court repairs", "wife's tampons", like Hawthorne's scarlet letter. Lord Saatchi would be pitching to us if he didn't want a job in No. 10. We have been meeting on committees just to watch the faces flash with shock as it dawns on them that the government might want to hobble the ability to call a leadership challenge. "We've done them before. Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth. So the fact that it is the only advanced nation to experience rising maternal mortality should be seen as a pretty shocking failure. But how and why exactly is America so bad at providing better care to its pregnant population and decreasing the death rate?

President Trump’s decision Monday to revive plans to freeze federal employee pay in 2020 and to institute a series of cuts to federal employee retirement programs was met with great consternation from stakeholder groups, although the ideas stand little chance of becoming reality.
Public employee groups had pointed to the threat of a pay freeze, which would apply to employees beyond the Social Security exclusion date of $1 to, as a “tipping point,” in their pleas to Congress to find a solution before the last two months of this fiscal year. President Trump has also kept a level, “0-percent” increase in the pay pool for the next fiscal budget even though Congress has made clear its intent to follow the rank-and-file schedule published by the White House’s Office of Management and Budget last Thursday. Pay would increase 2.9%, including a 1.9 percent increase for locality pay.
Beyond the pay pool, the brazen assault on retirement benefits was the most concerning for public employee groups that represent rank-and-file federal workers and retirees.

Nike Inc enjoyed big sales in gains in North America and Europe last quarter and benefited from fewer markdowns, helping the maker of sports clothes and shoes report a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit.
Total revenue rose 7.7 percent to $6.37 billion, excluding revenue from its Converse footwear business.
Analysts had expected $6.27 billion, on average, according to Thomson Reuters data.
Including Converse, the company said net income fell to $96 million (€68.5 million), or 28 cents per share, for the second quarter, from $305 million, or 44 cents, a year earlier.
On an adjusted basis, the company earned 49 cents per share.
Analysts had expected, on average, a profit of 41 cents per share.
Sales in North America, Nike’s biggest market, climbed 13 per cent, while Europe’s sales jumped 7 per cent as countries in Southern Europe showed some signs of rebounding.
Nike Chief Executive Officer Mark Parker said the outlook for the full year was improved.

Passengers on an ICE travelling from Berlin to Saarbrücken were shocked after windows were shattered by what they believe were bullets.
Police are investigating after windows on the ICE high-speed train were shattered during the journey from the German capital to Saarbrücken on Saturday night.
The windows broke out around 9pm between the towns of Hanau and Dreieich on March 24.
Train travellers fled from the window-smashed carriage in a panic.
A medical worker was reported to have sustained an injury as they rushed passengers from nearby iced-over areas, according to media reports.
"It's mainly because of the window being broken and the panic of the passengers, not just due to the fall," Karoline Thoma, a spokesman for the Red Cross in Mainz, said, echoing the reports.
The train stewards and police said the impact of the bullets was so powerful that they couldn't have been shot from a small gun but similar to a rifle. However, the debris of the shattered windows showed the size and type of the ammunition used was still unclear in this case.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as our planetary collection grows, and telescopes advance to probe more and more planets, previous rules of habitability may be replaced with novel criteria. That is the suggestion from a newly discovered Earth-sized exoplanet, named Teegarden b.
Its size makes it the smallest rocky exoplanet that orbit in the habitable zones of their host stars. The habitable zone, where a planet could support liquid water, depends on a star’s type and brightness. Our sun’s habitable zone stretches from Venus to Mars, where temperatures are neither too hot nor too cold.
All the planets we previously thought were habitable orbit red dwarf stars, which are much cooler and dimmer than our sun. Records show that these stars support exoplanet seasons that are at least triple the length ours. That’s because, in the red dwarf habitable zone, one side of the planet is in perpetual dusk and sunlight never penetrates very deep into the atmosphere.
“Most planets follow the norm from our solar system,” said Michaël Gillon of

Mattel's Future: Happily Ever After?
Mattel has a plan for the rest of the year, but it seems to be playing a shorter game.
According to its most recent earnings release, Mattel (NASDAQ:MAT) seems to believe that its troubles are over. Segment sales and operating income beat its own expectations in each quarter during the first half of the year, although advertising and promotional expenses continue to weigh on its bottom line. Doll sales were strong, and getting key license deals completed (like The Toy Manufacturers' Association's partnership with Warner Bros. on Harry Potter toys) helped Mattel finish strong in the second quarter.
But can the toymaker continue those trends? Let's put Mattel's recent run in perspective and look at the tough challenges it could potentially face in the rest of its 2013 and 2014.
Mattel's ongoing difficulties have mainly stemmed from its sales outside of the U.S. and some of its sales within the U.S., where it competes with rivals like Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS) that offer Barbie competitors. Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems that grow 3ft tall. The substantial bright green stems form a rosette of long green leaves which sit all together at the base of the stems.
1. Diascia personata
During the summer, long stemmed mauve flowers are produced with broad white throats. The old flower stems die back leaving the new flowering stems taking over. It sounds like a complicated inveterate plant and was for a while only grown by a very select group of gardeners before it came back into fashion towards the end of the last century.
Originating from the Cape region in South Africa, Diascia personata is suited to free draining and sunny sites where other Diascia might struggle. I have been growing it for 40 years now

"I think Christmas presents in the shops and snow on the ground is the definition of Christmas," Clary said. "If the crackers aren't in the shops already, the Christmas spirit has been replaced by the credit crunch."

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Charles University in Prague.
Prague, that atmospheric, storied, magnificent old city, still so under-the-radar that you could wander off by yourself for hours on end and never need a map, being guided mostly by the marvelous Bohemian maze that is its cobbling-stone streets – its spiny crooks, its hourglass fragments, the millennial geometries Mr. Quasimodo might have suffered for in an aging, willful cathedral.
I visited old ruins and re-discovered the Barracks of Stalin in Barricades Square, the big black-red Soviet magazine with “Pravda” on it and all the shots through the windows. Just down the square is the Golem statue, the delightful, ghastly creature with the wizened face and magical powers, its hands now folded over its heart. According to the Supo report, the scale of the most recent threat is not as well-defined as in 2014, the last time the police issue laid out their assessment of the risk to Finland from domestic and foreign terrorism. "Especially since late 2013, when the conflict in Syria escalated, the threat picture has changed. GENEVA, Mar 18 2013 (IPS) - The current growth model is not sustainable. Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come from concerted actions at the local and national levels, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), and an expert group of the UN Economic Commission for Europe (ECE) conclude.
A lot of problems are linked to this, expert group chair Sven Siroux, the director of the Clean Technologies Centre at the Czech Technical University, told IPS. But if one wants to be systematic, the most challenging aspect is the decision on which tree to push first.
Among the many projects that are being tied to the choice of the specific tree, the most important are climate change and renewable resources. In Siroux´s view, they are closely linked.. "The choice just underlines the fact that the current development model is not sustainable, but I think we are all agreed on that," he said.
Politicians, on the other side, do not only have to decide "which tree to push and which to step on," but also which tree to mow down, he said "The third aspect is having enough political courage."

The federal government is accelerating Canada’s transition to a lower-carbon economy, even as conservative politicians in the provinces vow to scuttle key measures that would support that effort.
Natural Resources Minister Jim Carr endorsed an advisory council report Thursday that spells out an ambitious agenda for Canada’s strategy on climate change for years to come. And with even more reports on the matter landing on his desk, Carr said now is the time to act quickly — especially as the current political impasse in Alberta leaves climate policies in a kind of limbo.
The Conservatives opposed the first national plan laid out by the Harper government in 2015, and say they will undo it as soon as they gain power.
That leaves Carr overseeing an uphill battle to put the strategy — and political will — back on track, which he and Environment Minister Catherine McKenna say they’ll do by pushing ahead with no regrets moves, like the plan to plant two billion trees over 20 years, while also acting on Gerry Butts’ council report, called A Healthy Environment and A Healthy Economy.

Smartphones can play a very positive role as a new tool with ophthalmologists, shows a new study conducted by the Emory University.
Smartphones can be extensively used by ophthalmologists for viewing complex inner eye photos for diagnostic purpose. They can also help patients stay aware of their treatment by constantly monitoring health indicators.
Smartphones can contribute to new and beneficial approaches in ophthalmology, suggests a new review published in the June issue of the journal Ophthalmology.
The article, Behavioral Effects of Texting and Video Messaging, describes the successes and limitations of mobile devices for patients and ophthalmologists. Increased use of these devices could help to enhance care and promote patient education and adherence to treatment protocols.

I love how old movies portray New York City at Christmastime. Snow drifts gently to the ground. Carols are sung on street corners. Decorations light up the streets. And the tree at Rockefeller Center seems to spread it's magic throughout the entire neighborhood.
One of the great Christmas movies we have at our house is Elf, starring Will Ferrell. You just have to see him sing at the end. In one of his scenes, Kevin McCallister, of the Home Alone fame, says to do one thing right at Christmas and you are drenched with Christmas spirit: Put up a Jesse tree and decorate a very simple Christmas tree.
Jesse Tree, Papa, Grandpa, Mother Mary, Joseph, Kings, Shepherds
What is a Jesse tree? It's been around since about 800 A.D. When it is set up in homes and churches, it signifies our family tree from Jesse (King David) to Jesus. The earliest known Jesse trees used a year- long process to bring our household or church family through the Old Testament (which pointed us to Christ) using carvings, paintings or woodcuts into the history of the Old Testament - right up to Jesus birthing in a manger.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift the drought emergency in California, except for a small section of the northwest that includes Lake Shasta and other major reservoirs. Brown has blamed the past drought for exacerbating the state budget crisis.
Spokesman Evan Westrup said relief was in the air, noting that "basically the whole state has made strides with its water resources."

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Dorchester Avenue two minutes after receiving calls of the home fire at 2:50 a.m., said Juan Bonilla, Chicago Fire Department's district chief.
Firefighters rescued a woman and a girl to the third floor bedroom, Bonilla said. Firefighters battled flames on the second and third floor.
Bonilla said firefighters removed a 4-year-old girl from the stairwell. They later learned that the 4-year-old girl was in another room.
A man on the second floor escaped out of the window, Bonilla said. Four firefighters sustained minor injuries.
Bonilla said firefighters did not find the man's wife and child on the third floor. Firefighters then learned that the man's wife and daughter were on the second floor.
Bonilla said the woman received a minor injury and was taken to South Shore Hospital.
Family members confirm the resident who was rescued is 50-year-old wifes Gloria Luchette.
It's still unclear how the fire started, Bonilla said.

History is filled with stories of bold pioneers who changed the world with their visionary ideas. There exists also, in the annals of innovation, a rich tradition of mad scientists with crazy inventions. These two notions are not mutually exclusive. In fact, so many visionary pioneers over the years have been truly crazy. "Mad" can be seen as a flowery word for brilliant. It's the flip side of the brilliance of the most brilliant working. The line between madness and genius is very fine; after all, since 2007, the actor Dennis Hopper still remains a patient of the UCLA Neuropsychiatric Hospital for paranoid schizophrenia with latent features of schizoaffective disorder. 1 Denzel Washington and Joaquin Phoenix as a modern-day Sherlock Holmes and down-to-earth Dr. Watson inspired us to find our modern-day mad geniuses. We were surprised to find out that five of the six mad geniuses on our list still stand pat with us in the battle between madness and mind, furthering the dream of great scientists of the past and--more importantly--important visions of the future we have come up with here. IF you like cricket, and like a brainy writer whose intellectualism is friendly and endearing, you’d better read this book. Mike Brearley was a cricketer with modest abilities, but he possesses a beautiful mind. Most creditable – and amusing – of all, however, he played himself in when writing about those players he knew and loved best like Colin Cowdrey.
Few cricketers can do that, can they? As a sports player or team member, you want to make the best and most winning team you possibly can. It's a perfectly natural thing to do, isn't it? If nobody in the team knows how to bowl leg-spin, you naturally bowl a few leg spinners? If everyone around you bats and bowls well, you naturally try to bowl and bat well, not shake up the team by batting for twelve with the tail, trying to score 100 and getting 0 and 99, at a time when you are privately thinking that lot batting so well seem a bit boring, famous and, well, not really cricket.
While there are sly, wry comments about some of his team-mates' character and idiosyncrasies, the book is in essence gentle, timeless

Assures reporters will not be blocked from covering Asean summit in Vientiane.
Laos yesterday defended its latest regulations imposed on foreign journalists, saying it would not prevent foreign media from covering the 2016 Asean due to be held in the capital next month.
Shortly before the 49th Asean Ministerial Meeting in Vientiane, Laos’ Foreign Ministry recently informed foreign media representatives in the country about a set of strict requirements that now seem to conflict with rules that have been applied in past years.
The latest strict requirements were first uncovered by foreign media and revealed by VoA.
Responding to a question from reporters on the matter yesterday, director of the ASEAN Department of Foreign Ministry Thongchanh Douangmany said Laos would do its best to ensure freedom of the press to guarantee that those requirements would not hamper journalists’ access to the site of the Asean summit.
“We want to give foreign journalists the same chance and access to cover the 49th Asean Ministerial Meeting like they did at the previous year’s summit in Kuala Lumpur,” he said. “We don’t think those requirements will prevent them from covering our chronical event.”

The scene of the fatal stabbing of a man in his 60’s at a house on Rutland Grove, Crumlin at about 8pm last night. Photograph: Colin Keegan/ Collins Dublin.
A man in is 60s has been stabbed to death in what gardaí are treating as a “deliberate attack” in west Dublin.
The victim was found in his home at Lavaler Terrace, in Rutland Grove, Crumlin at about 8pm last night.
The man was shouting in the street and lunged at nearby residents with a knife. He was removed from his home after firefighters managed to force entry to the property to deal with a fire.
Gardai have launched a murder investigation and issued a description of a suspect.
They are seeking to trace a man in his late teens or early 20s who was wearing a navy tracksuit top and bottoms, black boot and red socks at Crumlin Shopping Centre about 7.30pm last night.

CHICAGO–UAL Corp.'s United Airlines yesterday became the latest airline to begin charging $15 (U.S.) to check a single bag on domestic flights, matching the controversial fee launched in May by AMR Corp.'s American Airlines, the country's largest carrier.
The fees, part of the industry's efforts to offset soaring fuel costs and meet an expected rise in passenger demand during upcoming holiday travel periods, are widely considered to be the industry's biggest profit-generating change since Sept. 11, 2001, when passenger traffic fell by more than a third.
The following are the carriers that now charge separately for checked baggage, including acquisition fees to join their frequent-flier loyalty programs, usually at least $500. Most fees were introduced in May, while Northwest, EL Al and bmi are set to begin charging their fees on Oct. 15.
The new fees don't cover frequent-flier program credits (El Al is an exception), fees assessed for excess weight or oversize baggage, and fees to change or cancel a reservation. The number in parentheses represents the highest fee assessed on international flights, usually 50 to 100 per cent greater then domestic charges. Some airlines charge fees to upgrade to business- or first-class

Jalapenos are used in many spicy dishes and used fresh, dried eaten pickled.
Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers, like jalapenos, need a long warm growing season, as they are one of the most popular peppers in the country, along with the Anaheim pepper.
Green and Red Jalapenos
The jalapeno is a plant predominantly grown in southwest United States and Mexico. It is a pepper that is harvested in different states in the US, of which New Mexico is the leading producer of the seeds, while California and Texas are contributing significantly to the crop.
Believed to be one of the oldest hot peppers grown, the first claim of its’ growing in New Mexico is made by the early Spanish missionaries. However, it is also believed to have originated in the northern parts of Mexico where crosses of the hot peppers are believed to have taken place. Some of the pepper genuses are Guiliandella Capsicum, Dubaya and California. With slightly smaller leaves and swollen stems, this pepper plant is believed to be the origin of the cayenne and chili peppers.
Jalapenos have a woody, mottled green stem

HELENA – A state panel heard four hours of testimony Wednesday on bills relating to missing and murdered Indigenous women, an issue that proponents said affect all Montanans, but could have a profound impact on the Native American community.
House Bill 524 would create a commission to study patterns of industry violent crime against Native American women in Montana. The bill would require the commission to study crime, strategies, policies and implementation of eliminating the instances of violent crimes against Native American women in American Indian reservations and areas where there are large populations of Native Americans.
House Bill 552 would set up an expert panel to look at how to address human trafficking. It would study human trafficking in Montana, including its victims, where it is happening and how to address it. The panelists would primarily focus on Native American women in Montana, who advocates asked the panel consider to be the only real priority in the study.
House Bill 499 would create a commission to study the issue of missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls. It would require the commission to collect information and data and study the trend of the missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls, the causes of the trend and the strategies to eliminate missing and murdered Indigenous women and girls in Montana.

Mismanagement and secrecy have stalled the war on terrorism—and at home its effects reverberate against civil rights.
If September 11 was this generation's Pearl Harbor, the Bush Administration's war on terrorism is still in early 1942, when, ignorant of the Japanese's hopelessly inferior skills, the Americans sat on their hands and waited for Tokyo to pounce.
The easy analogy is between the State Department's famous pre-World War II parlor assessment that America and Europe could survive a Hitler defeat and political activist William Allen White's remark "Japan is not yet even hunting whales in the North Atlantic, let alone planning the invasion of the U.S." The better comparisons are between our current Cabinet meetings in the most modern offices in the world and Winston Churchill's meetings in the century's most sophisticated hot house, the Cabinet Room in the White House, painted and furnished by the ornate West Wing's finest designers. As Churchill prepared to follow Roosevelt to war, three weeks after the madness of September 11, the conservative British thinker contemplated and mourned the national failures, in us and the world, that left civilizations in the condition promised by today's high committee chat rooms.

FMCG major Hindustan Unilever (HUL) on Thursday reported a 9 per cent increase in its net profit to Rs 1,444 crore for the December 2018 quarter on account of strong volume growth and improved margins.
New Delhi: FMCG major Hindustan Unilever (HUL) on Thursday reported a 9 per cent increase in its net profit to Rs 1,444 crore for the December 2018 quarter on account of strong volume growth and improved margins.
The company had posted a net profit of Rs 1,342 crore in the same quarter last fiscal, HUL said in a statement.
Quarterly revenue from operations grew at a rate of 10 on year-on-year (YoY) basis, on the back of strong volume growth being offset by a slightly softer pricing environment. The revenue stood at Rs 8,942 crore for the period under review (December 2018 quarter).
On a year-on-year basis, turnover increased by 11 per cent to Rs 8,945 crore. The number was largely driven by volume growth which grew 12 per cent on a year-on-year basis, it said.

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Combined with mobile Internet access, GPS (global positioning system) technology in the mobile phones of 604 million people worldwide could offer something for everyone - and especially Generation Y, digital-spaces or otherwise, in coming years.
Surprised? You might not be now.
Gartner, the Florida-based consulting firm and elder statesman of forecasting, expects that number of GPS-equipped mobiles to grow to 1.9 billion by 2011, more than one mobile phone in four.
Technology forecasters and companies alike already assumed the majority of new mobiles will be GPS enabled in some form in time. Think reverse-GPS and location-aware chat.
Global positioning chips now being offered by nearly every major chip supplier pack a few technologies together into a small silicon package, including the GPS receiver and add-ons for now also tracking users indoors and outdoors on linear and pedestrian routes.
So far, the GPS may have seemed to be a little too futuristic, often limited to the most high-end, status-brand cellphones and restricted to a relatively small user group

Between saddles and strops, suffocating bottle dressings and overly sensitive paper, the art of wine preservation is one area of the industry ripe for disruption. In a Sunday morning hunch, one smart young Napa vintner thought of the familiar travel adaptor so adroitly changing the plug of a phone to a different wall socket; what about the cork? So he hired an engineer and within the month the ieciDaVina had been perfected.
Grapevines, like any plant, want to grow and reproduce. We graft two different varieties together mainly for the vigour and size of one and the flavour qualities of the other. A neutrino event, identifiable by the rings of Cerenkov radiation that show up along the photomultiplier tubes lining the detector walls, showcase the successful methodology of neutrino astronomy. This image shows multiple events.
Sometimes, the best-designed experiments blow up in the lab. But that hasn’t stopped scientists from looking for entirely undetectable particles that flit through the universe—but physicists are relying on a less conventional method to spot the elusive neutrino. The method hinges on a well-tested physical phenomena, as it’s been used for decades to detect electromagnetic radiation. It’s extremely useful, but relies heavily on pattern recognition, and fails when humans aren’t involved. Meet the subject of our latest Mad Scientist Alert, the Cerenkov radiator. Read on to find out about its important role in the recently-updated investigation that could finally find dark matter—the energy-eating, galaxy-warping expanse thought to fill about 85 percent of the universe that scientists can’t explain.
Dark matter leaves a radioactive trail
Dark matter sends off neutrinos, which may be detected by a Cerenkov radiator.

To help solve this problem, Andrew Foote and Emily Woods started Sanivation— No. 55 on the BI 100: The Creators — a sanitation startup that installs in-home toilets in East Africa and turns the waste into briquettes, bran, and ready-to-use therapeutic foods.
“People in trades like charcoal or brick making, which you can easily get started in with no investment, can make $2 a day,” says Foote. Add toilet access and the ability to earn a living, and suddenly poverty’s a lot less comfortable. In fact, in a pilot study in the Kenyan hills, over 90 percent of toilet users continued to use them a year later. Backed by Google for Entrepreneurs, Sanivation already works with 6,000 users. And soon even Kenya’s forests—which have been under threat from unregulated charcoal burning for years—will stand a fighting chance. “It hasn’t been easy, and things seldom go as planned,” says Woods. “But it doesn’t matter how many times people say a start- up like ours can’t work if you believe in your mission.” sanivation.com

MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market where the U.S. firm trails mainly Chinese vendors. Apple is expanding its manufacturing options in Asia, including a massive new plant in Texas due to start production by 2020, as China becomes costlier and demand grows in emerging market countries. Since it started selling its high-end phones in India more than two years ago, Apple has seen its iPhone market share in the country grow from 2 percent in 2015 to 3 percent in 2016 to 3.4 percent in 2017, according to Counterpoint Research. In 2016, barely 9 percent of the 265 million phones sold in India were in Apple’s high-end pricier segment where it operates, Counterpoint Research reported. In July this year, the research firm predicted that in the near future, the iPhone maker will eye the middle-end user, a group that cannot afford the iPhone X. Fans, coaches and players -- not just officials -- need to step up their games before disaster strikes.
If you follow me on social media (the math involving my modest number of followers says it’s unlikely) you know I’ve been consistent in my criticisms of the officiating in college basketball. I’ve suggested, in this space, in tweets (both “regular” ones and the oranges that are on ESPN.com) and on assorted radio and television shows, that this is the busiest time of the year in college basketball, there are too few referees, games take forever to play out and college basketball is missing a great opportunity to use today’s contemporary technology to solve certain issues related to officiating, among many other things that have been passed along to me through the years.

agencies at the local, state and federal level all employ marketing professionals in areas including, but not limited to, public relations, property disposal, bond sales and purchasing.
Almost all major government agencies have their own public-relations staff, and in many cases it is a stand-alone department with a public relations or media director and several support staff. Government agency PR departments are responsible for producing news releases, holding press conferences, and generally promoting activities of the agency, such as tourism or encouraging new businesses to move into the area.
Government agencies are constantly buying supplies, equipment and other property and selling off old equipment and property. The departments tasked with disposing of this government property often hire individuals with a background in marketing. Their job is to assist the agency in coming up with creative ways to sell or otherwise dispose of obsolete government property.
Most government agencies have to follow complicated regulations for purchasing supplies and equipment. In many cases, agencies can only buy from certain suppliers or can only buy goods within specific price ranges. Agencies

the WHO, put processed meats on the top of their “things that cause cancer list”, grouping them alongside tobacco, asbestos and diesel fumes, for which there is “sufficient evidence” of cancer links.
Along the years, there have been many studies that linked processed and red meats with cancer (especially bowel cancer), but there were always some doubts floating about. Now, the 22-member panel analyzed animal experiments, studies of human diet and health, and cell mechanisms that could lead from these meats to cancer.
“These findings further support current public health recommendations to limit intake of meat,” Dr. Christopher Wild, who directs IARC, said in a statement.
The decision wasn’t unanimous though, and a “probably” still crept in to the report. Many studies show the links, both in populations of people and in tests that show how eating these foods can cause cancer, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) said in its report, released in the Lancet medical journal.

“We have already done a lot of deficit reduction,” he said in an interview on NBC. Lew spoke on four TV talk shows, setting out Obama’s priorities ahead of an expected showdown this fall.
By early November, Congress must raise the legal limit on the country’s borrowing authority or risk an unprecedented default on the government’s debt.
A debt ceiling showdown in August 2011 between Obama and congressional Republicans sparked wild stock market swings and cost the United States its top-tier AAA credit rating.
“We need to get the debt limit extended in a way that doesn’t create a crisis,” Lew said.
Republicans see the debt ceiling as the their best leverage in winning a deal with Obama that would cut federal government spending to lower the deficit.

of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.
A person's diet is crucial if they are experiencing diarrhea. Some foods might help relieve symptoms of diarrhea while eating other foods can make diarrhea worse.
While recovering from diarrhea, a person should eat bland, simple foods that are easy to digest and will help absorb some water from

The force propelling pension funds and insurance companies into unfamiliar EM investments is simple. If they stay at home, their investment returns are at risk of falling short of their liabilities.
"If you require, say, 5 percent a year in order to cover your insurance or pension liabilities, that is not available from developed market (debt) obviously," said Colm McDonagh, head of emerging market fixed income at Insight Investment.
Brett Diment, head of emerging market debt at Aberdeen Asset Management, also sees a diversification into EM debt by pension and insurance companies. "We are seeing a broader group of investors looking at the emerging market debt asset class, including some insurers and pension funds that have not looked before."

Nevada's effective monopoly on sports betting ended last spring, when the Supreme Court ruled the ban should be lifted. Casinos in seven other states — Rhode Island, Delaware, Mississippi, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and New Mexico — now accept wagers on sports. The list is expected to grow by next year with numerous states considering bills.
And there's already a hitch that could slow bets: NASCAR this season has decided for the first time to strip drivers of victories if their cars are deemed illegal. There will be a roughly 90-minute inspection after the race and the winner will not be deemed official until the process is completed. Will fans really want to linger around the pay window another couple of hours just to cash in a ticket?
"The state's risk manager will delay any payout until NASCAR releases the official order of finish," Kirk said.

On Valentine’s Day 2007, Lynn Blake was embarking on a new job in Vail Village when she had a rude awakening. The 27-year-old suffered sudden cardiac arrest. Fortunately for her, someone trained in CPR stepped forward and kept her heart beating until emergency personnel arrived with a defibrillator. If someone dropped in front of you unconscious, with no notable pulse, would you know what to do? Some 325,000 people die every year of sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) in the United States. And, contrary to popular belief, it strikes people of all ages. “I did not know a thing about cardiac arrest. I didn’t know what it was,” Blake said. Now she knows firsthand about sudden cardiac arrest. The more she found out, the more she wondered why more people weren’t educated about SCA, the leading causes of death in the U.S. Just a few months after Blake’s sudden cardiac

two American women die of pregnancy-related causes every day may come as a surprise.
According to the World Bank, The US ranks 50th in maternal mortality globally - falling behind every other industrialised nation. A woman in the US is as likely to suffer a maternal death as a woman in sanctions-hit Iran, and four times as likely as a woman in Germany.
"It is a preventable health issue," said Amnesty International's Rachel Ward. "It isn't something that we're waiting for a cure for. We’re waiting for political will."
What's worse is that US maternal mortality rates may actually be on the rise. Eugene Declercq, of Boston University's School of Public Health, produced a short film named Birth by the numbers, discussing maternal mortality in the US. In a 2013 follow-up report, he noted how mortality rates in other industrialised nations had declined - but in the US, it increased by 30 percent in the first decade of the new millennium.

It’s not the food—the grub is OK, if not exactly slimming; it’s the gas generators powering the carts. Most food carts run off a diesel generator that’s designed to run only a few hours. Vendors run them for stretches of up to 14 hours, leading to a high output of greenhouse-gas emissions such as carbon monoxide, nitrous oxide, and particulate matter. You can see the smoke with the naked eye, but the hard facts are even more frightening: The research and consulting firm Energy Vision found that each cart produces the same amount of nitrous oxide as 186 cars on the road.

In its milestone report, “The Limits to Growth”, published in 1972, the Club of Rome warned that the human ecological footprint had grown dangerously quickly from 1900 to 1972. Shortly thereafter, the warning proved to be prophetic: by 1986 the human ecological footprint had overshot the carrying capacity of the Earth. At current production and consumption levels, we need 1.5 planets to survive; if everyone lived like a U.S. citizen, we would need five planets.
Land, water and biodiversity continue to decline. Global CO2 emissions are on the rise. The oceans are warming and the sea level is rising continuously. Forest cover has decreased by 300 million hectares since 1990.

The study also included the inner-eye photos taken by the ER staff using an ocular camera.
Then the study team assessed the response of two ophthalmologists who viewed and rated the pictures on a desktop PC and did the same on an iPhone.
The results of the study, published in the Archives of Ophthalmology, show that the doctors found the iPhone images good or better than desktop images and rated them high.
While one ophthalmologist felt 53 pictures were of the same quality, he found 46 better on iPhone and just one was better on PC.
For the other ophthalmologist who participated in the study, 56 were of equal quality, while 42 were better on iPhone leaving only two better on PC.

many celebrated breakthroughs were initially met with scorn and ridicule. We've compiled 11 such world-famous ideas from the history of science and technology. The temptation, of course, is to include those ideas that were scorned and should have stayed scorned. The Star Wars prequels, say. But we're trying to run a classy operation here.
Heliocentrism Galileo Galilei, sometimes called the Father of Modern Science, was among the first and most famous to pay a price for his crazy scientific ideas. Galileo publicly promoted the Copernican concept of heliocentrism -- that the Earth revolves around the Sun -- back when the Church and even most fellow mathematicians held to geocentric model. Unfortunately, in 17th century Rome, such radical ideas were quite literally heresy. Galileo was forced to recant and spend the rest of his life under house arrest.

IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested cluster that is powered by Advanced Micro Devices Inc.s 64-bit Opteron processor.
IBM, of Armonk, N.Y., is combining its Opteron-based eServer 325 server—which targets scientific and technical computing users—with systems management software and storage devices to offer a bundled package that can run Linux and Windows operating systems.
The new offering, which will be available later this month or in early December, is part of IBMs eServer Cluster 1350, which also includes bundles based on the companys BladeCenter blade servers and two-processor x335 and x345 systems using Intel Corp.s 32-bit Xeon chips.
Clusters comprise multiple servers tied together to create a supercomputing environment for users. In a related move, IBM last week announced that it was teaming with Corning Inc., the U.S. Department of Energy and the National Nuclear Security Administration to develop high-speed, optically switched interconnects for supercomputers. Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies in a number of capacities. Government agencies at the local, state and federal level all employ marketing professionals in areas including, but not limited to, public relations, property disposal, bond sales and purchasing.
Almost all major government agencies have their own public-relations staff, and in many cases it is a stand-alone department with a public relations or media director and several support staff. Government agency PR departments are responsible for producing news releases, holding press conferences, and generally promoting activities of the agency, such as tourism or encouraging new businesses to move into the area.
Government agencies are constantly buying supplies, equipment and other property and selling off old equipment and property. The departments tasked with disposing of this government property often hire individuals with a background in marketing. Their job is to assist the agency in coming up with creative ways to sell or otherwise dispose of obsolete government property.
Most government agencies have to follow complicated regulations for purchasing supplies and equipment. In many cases, agencies can only buy from certain suppliers or can only buy goods within specific price ranges. Agencies

MIDDLETOWN, NJ - The Middletown Township Public Library and the Township of Middletown are pleased to announce the appointment of Kim Rinaldi as Provisional Library Director, beginning on February 24, 2014. Ms. Rinaldi will earn a salary of $95,000.00 per year.
Ms. Rinaldi comes to the Middletown Township Public Library after having served as the Library Director of the Margaret E. Heggen Free Public Library in Washington Township, New Jersey. During her tenure in Washington Township, Ms. Rinaldi managed 26 employees and a $2.5 million annual budget. Ms. Rinaldi has also served as the Director of the Brielle Public Library and as a Senior Librarian at the Ocean County Library, Long Beach Island Branch in Surf City, New Jersey.
Ms. Rinaldi holds a Masters in Library and Information Science from Texas Women’s College and has extensive experience in library administration, budgeting and project management. Ms. Rinaldi is credited with outsourcing material cataloging and processing at the Margaret E. Heggan Free Public Library, reducing annual operating costs by $150,000.00. Ms. Rinaldi

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), part of the WHO, put processed meats on the top of their “things that cause cancer list”, grouping them alongside tobacco, asbestos and diesel fumes, for which there is “sufficient evidence” of cancer links.
Along the years, there have been many studies that linked processed and red meats with cancer (especially bowel cancer), but there were always some doubts floating about. Now, the 22-member panel analyzed animal experiments, studies of human diet and health, and cell mechanisms that could lead from these meats to cancer.
“These findings further support current public health recommendations to limit intake of meat,” Dr. Christopher Wild, who directs IARC, said in a statement.
The decision wasn’t unanimous though, and a “probably” still crept in to the report. Many studies show the links, both in populations of people and in tests that show how eating these foods can cause cancer, the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) said in its report, released in the Lancet medical journal.

WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. Treasury Secretary Jack Lew on Sunday warned Congress against manufacturing a crisis over federal spending in the months ahead, as looming deadlines set the stage for a repeat of the political deadlock which two years ago triggered worldwide financial market turmoil.
In coming negotiations with Republicans, who control the House of Representatives, Democratic President Barack Obama will focus on ways to create economic gains for the middle class over spending cuts, Lew said.
“We have already done a lot of deficit reduction,” he said in an interview on NBC. Lew spoke on four TV talk shows, setting out Obama’s priorities ahead of an expected showdown this fall.
By early November, Congress must raise the legal limit on the country’s borrowing authority or risk an unprecedented default on the government’s debt.
A debt ceiling showdown in August 2011 between Obama and congressional Republicans sparked wild stock market swings and cost the United States its top-tier AAA credit rating.
“We need to get the debt limit extended in a way that doesn’t create a crisis,” Lew said.
Republicans see the debt ceiling as the their best leverage in winning a deal with Obama that would cut federal government spending to lower the deficit.

In case you missed it, the initials ICYMI stand for the first five words of this sentence. In the event you have, indeed, missed it (ITEYH, I, MI has not taken off yet for some reason), it’s most likely because you’re not on the Internet much, particularly Twitter, where individuals and outlets deploy it every few seconds to bring links to the attention of others who may not have seen them. The New York Times now even has a section at the bottom of its app called “In Case You Missed It” with articles from previous days.
While the extended phrase has been used in conversation for a long time, the shorthand betrays an anxiety central to the Internet epoch. There is simply too much readable, viewable and listenable data for anyone to stay abreast of, as a humor piece, “I’m All Caught Up!” by Nick Mickowski in McSweeney’s, playfully suggested.

NEW YORK — Television retailer QVC has made aggressive plans to keep shoppers watching — instead of mall-hopping — on Black Friday, an event it has traditionally ignored.
The leading network for TV shoppers promises special deals and a healthy dose of new items for sale starting on Thanksgiving night. Program host Dave James plans to stay awake for 28 hours of telethon-like coverage.
The day after Thanksgiving is traditionally the biggest shopping day of the year, called “Black Friday” because it’s key for many businesses to go in the black, or turn a profit. QVC, which competes with ShopNBC and the HSN home shopping network, has not wanted to get caught up in the frenzy and has always treated it as just another day for its sales pitches, said Doug Rose, the network’s vice president of programming and marketing.
“This year, and we’ve been planning on this for many months, we really expect to join the fray with the other retailers,” Rose said.

Occasional diarrhea is a common occurrence. Most people will experience an episode of diarrhea at least once or twice a year that will disappear in a couple of days.
Luckily, there are many foods to eat that may help a person reduce the symptoms of diarrhea. There are also some foods to avoid when dealing with a bout of diarrhea, and some additional home care tips to consider.
Anyone who is experiencing persistent diarrhea should see a doctor, as a person may become dehydrated over time.
Diarrhea is a bowel movement that is more liquid than solid or has a loose texture. It is a common problem and may occur a couple of times each year. Diarrhea will usually last no more than 3 days.
Soft, bland foods, such as toast, will help to absorb excess water and ease the symptoms of diarrhea.
People with chronic digestive conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or Crohn's disease, may experience diarrhea more regularly.
A person's diet is crucial if they are experiencing diarrhea. Some foods might help relieve symptoms of diarrhea while eating other foods can make diarrhea worse.

Record low and negative interest rates in developed economies are fueling a ravenous search for yield that is forcing pension funds and other conservative institutional investors out of their comfort zones and into risky emerging markets, according to fund managers and analysts.
The reason for this has little to do with the attractiveness of EM investments. On the contrary, EM economic growth is at its lowest level since the 2008/09 financial crisis while the prospect of a U.S. monetary tightening creates the potential for financial turbulence.
The force propelling pension funds and insurance companies into unfamiliar EM investments is simple. If they stay at home, their investment returns are at risk of falling short of their liabilities.
"If you require, say, 5 percent a year in order to cover your insurance or pension liabilities, that is not available from developed market (debt) obviously," said Colm McDonagh, head of emerging market fixed income at Insight Investment.
Brett Diment, head of emerging market debt at Aberdeen Asset Management, also sees a diversification into EM debt by pension and insurance companies. "We are seeing a broader group of investors looking at the emerging market debt asset class, including some insurers and pension funds that have not looked before."
Much of this search for yield

Major League Baseball's annual amateur draft begins today and, by all expectations, Deardorff shouldn't have to wait long for his phone to ring.
The most pessimistic of scenarios would have him being taken in the fifth round. The most optimistic is a first round selection. Most likely, though, the call could come sometime during the second or third rounds.
Baseball America has projected Deardorff, who graduated from South Lake High School Friday, as the 54th overall pick, which would make him a second round choice.

"I have no idea," he said, about where he would be drafted. "People have said a lot of things, but I don't want to say anything in case it doesn't happen."

Aylesbury’s new deputy area commander has been getting stuck in to his new role and says he’s determined to make himself ‘approachable’.
Chief inspector Neil Kentish joined Thames Valley Police less than a month ago after serving in the Metropolitan police force for 14 years.
And though the role is still very new to him, he has praised his team and says he wants to find out what issues matter to people in Aylesbury.
He said: “I have a very positive team and they genuinely care about what they do.
“The people of Aylesbury already have confidence in the force so it’s about maintaining that confidence, tackling anti-social behaviour, understanding the local community and alleviating people’s concerns.
During his time with the Met, chief insp Kentish – who lives in Milton Keynes with his wife and children – was one of the first neighbourhood officers to patrol White Hart Lane in Tottenham, London.

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
The UAE, which has peacekeepers in Afghanistan, awarded Sikorksy Aircraft a US$171 million (Dh628m) contract for 14 UH-60 Black Hawk helicopters, which are used for tactical transport.
Separately, the US defence security co-operation agency, a unit of the Pentagon, said last week it had notified Congress of a potential sale of enhanced guided bomb units, parts, training and support to the UAE for about $290m.
The same agency said in November that in the last fiscal year the UAE became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment with sales of $7.9bn, ahead of Afghanistan ($5.4bn), Saudi Arabia ($3.3bn) and Taiwan ($3.2bn).
The spending included orders for munitions for the UAE’s F-16 fighter jets as well as a new Patriot defensive missile system and a fleet of corvettes for the navy.
The UAE purchases have been fuelled by a quadrupling of oil prices in the past decade and by continuing regional tensions, including those involving Iran

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday to push nervous Democrats to forge ahead on health care, despite voters' worries and opposition from newly strengthened Republicans. Sharpening his focus on the economy, he offered a hodgepodge of tax breaks and other incentives to create new jobs.
For Republicans, Obama blended a mix of overtures and digs. But he mainly addressed fellow Democrats, who still can enact his agenda if they overcome fears fueled by events such as last week's stunning GOP victory in the Massachusetts Senate race.
That setback may have cost Democrats their filibuster-proof Senate majority, Obama said, but "we still have the largest majority in decades, and the people expect us to solve some problems, not run for the hills."
He accepted partial blame for the deep troubles facing his health care push, but he implored lawmakers to finish the task rather than yield to public opposition.

COUNCIL BLUFFS — The Marshalltown Community College baseball team built a nine-run lead and held on to salvage a split against NJCAA Division I No. 12 Iowa Western in Saturday’s Iowa Community College Athletic Conference doubleheader.
MCC won the nightcap 12-10 after Iowa Western claimed the opener 8-4.
The Tigers (19-29, 8-14) scored seven runs in the first inning of game two, sending 13 batters to the plate. The frame was highlighted by a Snayder Ruiz two-run single, and a Kaleb Hanks two-run triple. Ruiz finished game two with three RBIs while Hanks and Diogen Ceballos each drove in two. Jose Mieses, Ceballos and Adam Barrett had two hits apiece, both doubles for Ceballos, as the Tigers rapped out 12 hits in the victory.
The Reivers (40-14, 19-3) got seven runs back between the fourth and fifth innings to pull within two, but MCC came back with three in the sixth. The Tigers needed them all, as Iowa Western plated three in the bottom of the seventh.

Sponsored by Sen. Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency through 2024 to assist firms with rebuilding or retrofitting diesel engines. The objective is for those updated engines to be able to comply with pollution standards.
The Environment and Public Works panel advanced the measure to the floor of the Senate by voice vote. Carper, the panel’s ranking Democrat, had initially authored the bill more than a decade ago with former Ohio Sen. George Voinovich (R).
“With today’s vote, we’re one step closer to making sure this bipartisan tradition, imagined and incepted by my dear friend Sen. Voinovich, will continue to boost economic growth and encourage environmental progress,” Carper added. Voinovich died in 2016.
Co-sponsors of the bill include committee Chairman John Barrasso (R-Wyo.), as well as Republican Sens. Jim Inhofe of Oklahoma, Dan Sullivan of Alaska and Shelley Moore Capito of West Virginia, along with Democratic Sens. Graciousness might not seem like the most important thing in defining the success of a nation, but it is paramount for Mr Lim Siong Guan, the Institute of Policy Studies' fourth S R Nathan Fellow for the Study of Singapore.
Having served 37 years in the civil service, five of which as its head, Mr Lim said that based on his experience, there are four words to describe what Singapore needs in order to be a successful and sustainable nation state - "gracious society, Smart Nation".
He said: "We are a First World economy, but I don't think we can say that we are a First World society.
"We need to think about how to not just do good for ourselves, but also for future generations.
"We need to think about what kind of society we aspire to be."
He was speaking yesterday at the launch of his book, Can Singapore Fall? Making The Future For Singapore, which is a compilation of three lectures he delivered between September and November last year.
Mr Lim said that while thinking about the lectures, he came to the conclusion that to succeed and avoid "social decay", Singaporeans needed to think about the kind of society they aspired to be.

Robert E. Gates, 65, Altoona, passed away Friday at UPMC Altoona.
Known as Flip, he was born in Massachusetts, son of the late Patricia Gates. He married Cindy Thompson.
Surviving are his wife; two daughters: Heather Cramer (Laramy) of Coalport and Jessica Gates of Altoona; two sisters: Cheryl McKeen in Florida and Carol Martin of Indiana, Pa.; his mother-in-law, Joan Thompson; an aunt, Sandy Martin in Tennessee; and a granddaughter, Anna Cramer.
Bob served in the U.S. Marine Corps as a lance corporal. He retired from the Altoona Hospital Police Department with 38 years of service and also worked part-time for the Williamsburg Police Department. He was a member of Wehnwood United Methodist Church.
Friends will be received from 6 to 8 p.m. Monday, Feb. 11, 2019, in the Leslie E. Axe Funeral Home, 1520 Fourth St., Altoona, and from 10 to 11 a.m. Tuesday, Feb. 12, 2019, at the Wehnwood United Methodist Church. A funeral service will be held at 11 a.m. Tuesday

Lynn Blake, left, teaches two hospital employees CPR at the VVMC Safety Fair. Blakeâs passion for educating Eagle County residents came from her own Sudden Cardiac Arrest, which a bystander provided CPR and saved her life. She was just 27 at the time.
On Valentine’s Day 2007, Lynn Blake was embarking on a new job in Vail Village when she had a rude awakening. The 27-year-old suffered sudden cardiac arrest. Fortunately for her, someone trained in CPR stepped forward and kept her heart beating until emergency personnel arrived with a defibrillator. If someone dropped in front of you unconscious, with no notable pulse, would you know what to do? Some 325,000 people die every year of sudden cardiac arrest (SCA) in the United States. And, contrary to popular belief, it strikes people of all ages. “I did not know a thing about cardiac arrest. I didn’t know what it was,” Blake said. Now she knows firsthand about sudden cardiac arrest.
